awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to  Gabriel T.  Goldberg is "Ultrafilters and inner models". The host institution for the fellowship is University of California at Berkeley and the sponsoring scientist is John Steel.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The NSF postdoc project focused on set theory, specifically large cardinal hypotheses so strong that they contradict the Axiom of Choice. This exploration led to findings that are new and important to a wider mathematical discussion.

One notable discovery was a periodicity phenomenon among choiceless large cardinals; this was published jointly with Schlutzenberg who noticed the same pattern independently. The pattern is that under large cardinal assumptions beyond choice, the even and odd levels of the cumulative hierarchy behave in very different ways. 

A second main theorem was a uniqueness theorem for elementary embeddings assuming the Axiom of Choice. This is closely related to the HOD conjecture, a significant conjecture in set theory regarding the structure of sets definable from ordinal numbers, which was also a focus of the PI's research.

One of the key impacts of this work is an emerging consensus that the HOD conjecture is false. Other broader impacts include mentoring undergraduate and graduate students and contributing to the ongoing discussions in the philosophy of set theory.

The sharing of these findings through publications and presentations has encouraged more questions and discussions among the set theory community. Supported by the NSF, this project not only added to the existing knowledge but also opened up avenues for future investigations in set theory.


Last Modified: 10/30/2023
Modified by: Gabriel T Goldberg
